briefing.opening: Good morning/afternoon. Welcome to the climate briefing for February 2, 2026. Based on the 117 climate-related news items collected today, we will provide a comprehensive report on global and domestic climate change response efforts and the challenges we face.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Warnings of Climate System Tipping Points and Challenges for Carbon Neutrality Goals
sections.content: Key scientific research findings released today have repeatedly issued serious warnings that if carbon neutrality is delayed, the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC) could reach a 'tipping point' and collapse [3, 17, 19, 23]. Concurrently, domestic industries are expressing concerns about achieving the 2050 carbon neutrality goal, raising discussions on the need for pace adjustment and policy realignment [33, 38]. Furthermore, despite the urgent need to expand renewable energy, domestic energy transition policies face difficulties, as evidenced by onshore wind power bids falling short for three consecutive years [99]. The statement by the Chairman of the Hwaseong Special City Council, emphasizing that the climate crisis and carbon neutrality are key challenges determining urban sustainability, once again underscores the gravity of the current situation [56]. Internationally, complex risks of climate change impacting human society as a whole are being warned, including a U.S. climate skeptic panel being found in violation of the law while drafting a controversial report [109], and an analysis suggesting that climate change will limit future Olympic host cities [110].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Accelerating Climate Change Adaptation and Carbon Neutrality by Domestic Local Governments and the National Government
sections.content: Various domestic local governments and government agencies are continuing their proactive efforts to respond to climate change and achieve carbon neutrality. Gimcheon City in Gyeongbuk Province is accelerating its efforts by establishing a 'Climate and Energy Department' and undertaking organizational restructuring to build a control tower for climate change response and carbon neutrality policies [6, 7, 8, 13, 21, 75]. Cheonan City is comprehensively reorganizing its urban safety and climate response systems, pursuing a two-track strategy of AI-based disaster response and carbon neutrality to create a 'daily safe city' [24, 25, 26, 37, 39, 42, 47, 49, 50, 63, 71, 73, 74, 77]. Paju City is proactively responding to climate change by supporting frost damage prevention facilities for fruit farms [2, 10, 11]. The Korea Forest Service has established a legal foundation by implementing the 'Forest Disaster Prevention Act' to respond to forest disasters in the era of climate crisis [5, 12, 16, 18, 22]. The Ministry of SMEs and Startups is expanding support for carbon-neutral commercialization and has introduced an 'investment-linked type' program, providing up to 600 million KRW to promising SMEs to encourage green transition [27, 35, 36, 45, 53, 54, 59, 65, 66, 67]. Various regions, including Yongin City, Gyeonggi Province, Ganghwa County, Yuseong District, Gwangju City, Changwon City, Jinan County, Boryeong City, Jecheon City, and Donghae City, are contributing to climate crisis adaptation and carbon neutrality through diverse methods such as operating climate change experience programs, providing lifelong environmental education, reducing paper use, realizing carbon-neutral cities, creating 'sunshine income' villages, and promoting eco-friendly vehicles [1, 14, 15, 20, 29, 40, 41, 43, 44, 46, 55, 58, 61, 64, 68, 69, 70, 76, 78, 108].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Renewable Energy Transition Policies and Expansion of Supply
sections.content: Efforts to expand renewable energy supply to accelerate energy transition are spreading nationwide. Incheon Gyeyang District is expanding the supply of new and renewable energy to establish a low-carbon, eco-friendly urban foundation and is progressively implementing energy transition policies [34, 57, 60, 62, 80, 81, 82, 83, 87, 92, 95, 101, 102, 105]. Inje County is also expanding new and renewable energy supply by supporting over 400 solar and geothermal facilities [86, 88, 104]. The government plans to install solar facilities in 500 schools nationwide this year and invest 1.5 trillion KRW in renewable energy supply [84]. It is accelerating solar utilization and renewable energy expansion through the promotion of region-specific electricity tariffs and daytime discount policies for industrial electricity rates [52, 94]. The Ministry of Climate has declared this year as the first year of energy transition, aiming to achieve 100 GW of renewable energy and accelerate grid expansion [89, 90]. The case of tangerine production utilizing renewable energy presents a positive model that achieves both contributions to carbon neutrality and increased farmer income [28, 72].

sections.title: ğŸŒ International Climate Change Trends and the Importance of Communication
sections.content: Diverse movements to address climate change are being observed in the international community. Investments are concentrating on Japan's 'resilience bonds,' drawing international attention to climate change response efforts [4]. DHL is accelerating low-carbon logistics in the Asia-Pacific region by expanding the use of sustainable aviation fuel, electric vehicles, and renewable energy [97]. Large-scale renewable energy investment plans have also been announced, such as Elon Musk of Tesla declaring 100 GW of solar power [103]. Furthermore, amidst analyses suggesting that climate change acts as a geopolitical force that could lead to Arctic militarization and climate wars [112], discussions are actively taking place on how to effectively communicate climate change without excessive pessimism [106, 111]. Efforts by companies fighting against climate change, such as Centara Resorts in the Maldives [117], are also continuing, and media activities like the First Nations' climate change documentary series are contributing to raising awareness of the climate crisis [116].

briefing.closing: Today's briefing has highlighted that despite warnings about climate system tipping points and the challenges in achieving carbon neutrality, diverse efforts for climate change adaptation and renewable energy transition are continuously underway both domestically and internationally. In this era of climate crisis, it is crucial to heed scientific warnings and accelerate tangible actions. This concludes today's climate briefing.
